Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 12:30AM Law828 wrote: please make sure to follow up in 6 months or get a 2nd opinion.   Listen to you gutt feeling, your intuition.  I had a lump in 2002 and biopsy showed I was clear with dense breast.   2003 mammo asked for biopsy and 2002 biopsy was used to as everything is ok.  I trusted medicine and tried to cut back on the coffee (they told me that caused dense and fibrosis breast)  By 2011 I had a dimple forming and it kind of hurt.   Ultra sound showed positive on two lumps and suspicious lymph node.  Biopsy showed positive for all three.  Mastectomy showed positive but there was only one tumour the other two were lymph nodes.  Don't let it go like I did
Posts.Title: Had my mammogram anxiety79 Law828

Posts.Content: Law828 wrote: Found it on my spine and had radiation and chemo in 2013/2014. But now it is back and looking at possible surgery to remove it. Will find out after MRI is reviewed early this week. Just wondering if anyone has gone thru this? Either metastases to the same spot after treatment or if you have had surgery to your spine to remove the bad part. I have no other spots and I think this is why surgery is being considered. Thank you Dx 7/1/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 8/7/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 10/1/2013 Ixempra (ixabepilone), Xeloda (capecitabine) Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2013 07:30AM Law828 wrote: Me. I am now stage IV with one lesion on my spine. Started chemo and doing good so far. Will start with radiation in January. I'm not ready to quit
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Law828 wrote: Does anyone know if we give out bad odor while we are in treatment? I asked my husband tonight and he said no, never smelled anything. I am in treatment right now and I don't wear perfume or smelly scents, so if there is a bad smell......oh oh. I read that a lady undergoing chemo treatment for breast cancer stage 4 puts out a bad odor and was "banned" from attending activities with her 3 girls at school. The teachers claim her smell is nauseating and the principle said his mother had the same bad smell when she was going though chemo. I don't mind staying away from people to spare them, but the holidays are coming up and I will be close to family and friends. I think what that school in Albq. NM is doing is cruel or there must be more than what the media is reporting, but that little part is questioning if I smell bad. Incase you want to see the story: http://www.opposingviews.com/i/health/mom-and-cancer-patient-kerri-mascareno-smells-too-bad-isit-daughter-school-principal-says# http://www.ktsm.com/news/albuquerque-mom-cancer-banned-school Dx 7/1/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 8/7/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 10/1/2013 Ixempra (ixabepilone), Xeloda (capecitabine) Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo treatment gives bad odor? Law828 Padiddle

Posts.Content: Law828 wrote: Last time I used doxorubicin with cytoxan (AC) treatments every 2 weeks for a total of 4 treatments and that was tough for me.  Right away started paclitaxel (taxol) for treatment every week for total 12 treatments and this was much better but a stinker with my fingers (neuropathy) and black and numb toe nails.  Radiation every day for 7 weeks.   Now I find myself with a single lesion on my spine (biopsy shows metastatic of breast cancer) and I really want to live and no where ready to quit.  So I am now starting Ixempra 40 mg every 3 weeks for a total of 4-6 treatments and xeloda 3000 mg daily for 7 days on 7 days off.  Everywhere I read, I see unsuccessful stories and prognosis.  I am looking for anyone that has encouraging words to get me started on this journey with success on keeping a postivie outlook.  Looking for anyone that may have experiences with these drugs and have recommendations for me such as do not eat this or that, exercise no less than, etc.  I really trust what you have to say.  Like I tell my husband, you are all real people with real stories, you are not a text book or a statistic gathered by someone.  As of right now, I feel just like I did yesterday, except a little relaxed from the bendaryl and ativan they gave me prior to chemo.  When did you start to feel yukie after starting this treatment?   Thank You So Much Dx 7/1/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 4/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 8/7/2013, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 10/1/2013 Ixempra (ixabepilone), Xeloda (capecitabine) Radiation Therapy Bone Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New Stage IV Started ixabepilone and xeloda Law828 GrammyR

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 09:38PM Law828 wrote: Liz Lemon, I too was on tamoxafin for about 1 year and my tumor markers did not change one bit.  It was the pet scan and later MRI and bone scan that showed the lesion on my spine.  I did get my 2nd opinion from MdAnderson and they said it was aggressive treatment and radiation will be just as aggressive.  But they have hopes for very positive results and I am trusting them.  Where would I go for a 3rd opinion?  It seems doctors have different treatments for everyone and everone reacts different to the same treatment.....did that make any sense?  I have you ladies to share with me what you went through and even though I may not get it, I can be somewhat ready for it.  I don't want to quit the treatment because my body had a tough time, I dont want to quit. It makes me happy to see that the treatment has shown positive results for both of you.  You are giving me lots of hope and strength to be strong...Thank You
Posts.Title: New Stage IV Started ixabepilone and xeloda Law828 GrammyR

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2013 10:38PM Law828 wrote: Sometimes I think I can smell it too but often wonder if it's in my head. But I do know my urine smell has changed too. Ive heard dogs can smell cancer too, I only had the middle one (corgi) following me around every where I went. And just now I am realizing that she has not been following me like she was for about 2-3 weeks and coincidentally I had my 3rd round of chemo today. hhhhmmmmm
Posts.Title: Chemo treatment gives bad odor? Law828 Padiddle

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2015 06:31PM Law828 wrote: I am 55 years old and I never thought it would bother me wearing a prostheses on my right side, but it really bothers me the longer I wear it. I can never find bras that fit right, my left side sags now due to wearing bras with no support. It took me two years to find a bathing suit. I'm 5' 5" and weigh 190 with most of it in my tummy area. Reconstruction and radiation doctors both said the only option would be for me to have the diep going thru my mid section. My tests and scans have all been good since April of last year and when I spoke to my oncologist, he said I am good to go and to live like I am cancer free. My liver counts went up right before I was diagnosed and went higher when I was in chemo the first time. My pet read that I have a fatty liver, but after the mets and 2nd round of chemo my liver counts are very normal. After reading RonnieKay's experience, it scares me. My option would of been to have both removed and I could not get anyone to sign off on it for my surgeon to schedule me. And my 2nd oncologist told me that all mid section fat produces estrogen. That is what caused me to schedule my surgery. I am currently scheduled in October and I will be going back and fourth with my decision.
Posts.Title: Reconstructive Surgery ChicagoGirl Law828

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2018 07:24AM Law828 wrote: Yay! So happy for you and thank you for sharing because I too came searching long ago to see how many survivors there are hoping that I could be one of them one day. Today I am here and a survivor since 2011 and again 2013. I will find out next month if I am cancer free. I feel I AM cancer free and that is what I am sticking too. I live with a positive attitude, focus on what works and forget what didn't, stay stress free (and when I can't I exercise hard till the stress is out or craft), I really try hard to drink lots of water because I believe water flushes the bad cells and keeps them from planting in my organs or anywhere else. I'm happy we can all share our joys and our fears on here. God Bless all of you and always Smile BIG.
Posts.Title: Stage 4 survivor! Benzzz2018 LoveFromPhilly

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 09:16PM - edited Oct 3, 2013 09:23PM by Law828 I don't know why my stats wont show up.  But I am 53 and diagnosed 2 years ago with invasive ductal 2cm.  Of 13 nodes removed there were 4 positive.  I actually had the lump in 2002 and it never grew, at that time biopsy was negative for cancer and told good to go and mammo following year was good to go too, not to worry was what I got.  My grade is a 2 and I was beginning menopause when I started chemo, but as soon as I started chemo my periods stopped.  I was either stage IIb or IIIa (depending who you ask)  I am ER+ HER-.  Now I am stage IV with one lesion on my spine T6, biopsy proved it was bc, but a little confused with ER.  Report shows estrogen 90%, progesterone 1% and her 0%.  I was going to ask my doctor about it but too busy with 1st day of chemo. Chickadee, did you start to feel awful right away?  Did it get worst as time went on?  No appetite or nausea?  I guess I'm trying to set up a plan in my head so that I won't want to quit the treatment or have the dosage lowered.  My doctor feels 40 mg of ixempra may be too much and will reduced it if I start to feel bad.  I don't want to reduce it, instead I want to prepare myself to just deal with it (it wont be forever, though I'm sure it feels like it is).
Posts.Title: New Stage IV Started ixabepilone and xeloda Law828 GrammyR
